programme.title: The Many Faces of...
programme.desc: June Whitfield worked alongside the greats Arthur Askey, Tony Hancock, Frankie Howerd, Ronnie Barker, Benny Hill, Bob Monkhouse, Terry Scott and Jennifer Saunders. In this film June tells her own story, from her early days in the West End working with Noel Coward, her ill-fated Broadway debut, and with the help of rarely seen archive, impeccable comedy performances on radio and TV.

programme.title: Reginald D Hunter's Songs of The Border
programme.desc: Against the backdrop of President Trump's much-trumpeted wall, Reginald D Hunter takes a 2,000-mile road trip along the US-Mexico border to explore how romance and reality play out musically where third-world Mexico meets first-world US on this broken road to the American dream.

programme.title: Arctic with Bruce Parry
programme.desc: Bruce Parry journeys to the far north of Greenland, home to the last traditional Inuit hunters. Bruce experiences the realities of life - and death - on a seal hunt, and learns how climate change is threatening their ancient way of life. However, while global warming is causing problems for the hunters, it is providing others with new opportunities.

programme.desc: Terry Wogan introduces another round in the classic interregional amateur dance contest as Wales compete against the North West at the Top Rank Suite in Swansea. Ray Moore provides the commentary. Featuring latin, ballroom, old time, formation and disco.

programme.title: Romeo and Juliet: Beyond Words
programme.desc: As members of the feuding Capulet and Montague families, Romeo and Juliet should be sworn enemies, but they fall deeply in love and marry in secret. That very day, disastrous circumstances lead Romeo to fight and kill Juliet's cousin Tybalt, setting off a chain of events that culminate in tragedy.

programme.title: Westwood: Punk, Icon, Activist
programme.desc: Profile of punk fashion designer Vivienne Westwood, as she fights to maintain her brand's integrity, her principles and her legacy.

programme.title: Vivienne Westwood Talks to Kirsty Wark
programme.desc: Kirsty Wark interviews Vivienne Westwood about her career as one of Britain's most inventive and influential fashion designers. Filmed on location at her V&A retrospective, Vivienne Westwood discusses her career from the early days of designing clothes worn by the Sex Pistols to her catwalk shows. She gives an insight into how she works, including her use of very British fabrics such as Harris tweed and tartan and her reinterpretation of historic garments such as the corset and crinoline.

programme.title: Byzantium: A Tale of Three Cities
programme.desc: Historian Simon Sebag Montefiore traces the sacred history of Istanbul by uncovering the city's ancient Greek roots and charting its transformation into the Imperial capital of a Christian Empire.

programme.title: The Search for the Lost Manuscript: Julian of Norwich
programme.desc: Medieval art historian Dr Janina Ramirez tells the incredible story of a book hidden for centuries in the shadows of history, the first book ever written in English by a woman, Julian of Norwich, in 1373. Revelations of Divine Love dared to present an alternative vision of man's relationship with God - a theology fundamentally at odds with the church of Julian's time - and for 500 years the book was suppressed.

programme.title: Ancient Worlds
programme.desc: Richard looks at the winners and losers of the great Bronze Age collapse, and the new powers that emerged in the harder-edged Age of Iron.

programme.title: Sicily: The Wonder of the Mediterranean
programme.desc: Historian Michael Scott begins his journey through Sicily on the slopes of Mt Etna, Europe's largest active volcano. For the Ancient Greeks, the island was a land of gods and monsters, a dangerous and unpredictable world.

programme.title: Winterwatch
programme.desc: Chris Packham introduces a classic documentary from the BBC's archive, which takes a look at the worst winter of the 20th century in 1963. He also explores what we now know about how this big freeze affected Britain's wildlife, and how it would cope if we experienced another equally bad winter.

programme.title: Timeshift
programme.desc: Solar scientist Dr Lucie Green looks back through Britain's most dramatic weather history and sees how our reactions helped forge a weather science that today allows us to predict the worst extremes.

programme.title: The U.S. and the Holocaust
programme.desc: A group of government officials support rescue operations; the public sees for the first time the scale of the Holocaust as Allies liberate German camps.

programme.title: Ancient Worlds
programme.desc: Richard Miles explores the power and the paradox of the `Greek Thing' - a blossoming in art, philosophy and science that went hand-in-hand with political discord, social injustice and endless war. He paints a fascinating picture of the internal and external pressures that fuelled this unique political and social experiment, one that would pioneer many of the political systems that we still live with today.

programme.title: The Joy of Painting with Bob Ross
programme.desc: Bob creates a painting effect using masking tape. The sky and mountains are the backdrop for a meadow, evergreen trees and a footpath leading to a cabin. Bob removes the tape to reveal a triple-paned window effect.

programme.title: To the Manor Born
programme.desc: DeVere negotiates an important business deal with the beautiful Mademoiselle Dutoit, but when she decides to mix busisness with pleasure, he invents a wife... Audrey!

programme.title: The Mistress
programme.desc: Luke is on dangerous ground, with both Maxine and Helen feeling they could do with a bit more attention.

programme.title: A History of Britain by Simon Schama
programme.desc: Looking at the life of Henry II, a man who created the jury system, established the first legal statute books and built one of the greatest empires of the medieval world. Now, however, he is best remembered as the man who ordered the murder of his former friend and Chancellor, Thomas a Becket.

programme.title: Storyville
programme.desc: Three minutes of footage is all that remains of the Jewish community of Nasielsk, Poland, filmed in 1938 by photographer David Kurtz. Unravel the stories hidden in the celluloid, with insights from the film-maker's grandson and a boy who appears in the faded footage, one of the few survivors of the decimated village. David Kurtz's footage was made available, courtesy of the Steven Spielberg Film and Video Archive in the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum.

programme.title: The Lost Libraries of Timbuktu
programme.desc: Aminatta Forna tells the story of legendary Timbuktu and its long hidden legacy of hundreds of thousands of ancient manuscripts. With its university founded around the same time as Oxford, Timbuktu is proof that the reading and writing of books have long been as important to Africans as to Europeans.

programme.title: Horizon
programme.desc: Physicist Dr Helen Czerski and meteorologist John Hammond make sense of our recent extreme weather and discover that there is one thing that connects all our recent extreme winters - the Jet Stream, an invisible river of air.

programme.title: Hope Street
programme.desc: Finn is away receiving treatment for his PTSD, so Concepta takes his place on a fishing trip with Shay and Barry. Their pleasure cruise goes horribly wrong, however, when the boat's engine explodes, and crew member Brendan is seriously injured.

programme.title: Great British Railway Journeys
programme.desc: Michael Portillo continues his journey through western Scotland by exploring the industrial heartland of Glasgow and its mighty River Clyde before taking the ferry to the island of Cumbrae. He is put to work behind the scenes at Glasgow's circular subway, explores the future of shipbuilding on the Clyde.

programme.title: The Joy of Painting with Bob Ross
programme.desc: Bob Ross uses snowy mountain peaks as the backdrop for a winding waterway and evergreen trees.

programme.title: Michael Palin's New Europe
programme.desc: From the tiny, breakaway state of Transdniester to the rolling hills of sunny Moldova, across the Carpathian Mountains of northern Romania and through Transylvania to the Danube, this is a journey into some of the poorest and most beautiful parts of south-eastern Europe.

programme.title: The Beginning and End of the Universe
programme.desc: Professor Jim Al-Khalili journeys into the distant future to try to discover how the universe will end: with a bang or a whimper? He reveals a universe far stranger than anyone imagined and, at the frontier of understanding, encounters a mysterious and enigmatic force that promises to change physics forever.

programme.title: Maya Angelou on Robert Burns
programme.desc: African American writer and poet Maya Angelou goes on a pilgrimage to Burns Country in Scotland. She is welcomed to Ayrshire by a group of Burnsians who hold a party in her honour to celebrate Rabbie Burns's genius.

programme.title: Beyond Burns
programme.desc: Robert Burns' story has been told over and over, and with good reason. But in this programme Jackie Kay looks beyond Burns. She looks to some of the other extraordinary, and often overlooked, poets that Scotland has produced and continues to today.

programme.title: Catching Britain's Killers: The Crimes That Changed Us
programme.desc: In 1972, the body of Maxwell Confait was found, in a house in Catford, South London. After a short investigation, three local boys confessed to arson and murder. At the Old Bailey, all three were convicted, despite retracting their statements and protesting their innocence.

programme.title: Weather for the Week Ahead
programme.desc: Detailed weather forecast.

programme.title: Joins BBC News
programme.desc: BBC One joins the BBC's rolling news channel for a night of news.

programme.title: BBC News

programme.title: Talking Business
programme.desc: As the global economy falters, is 2023 shaping up to be a year of big job losses? After Microsoft became the latest big name in technology and banking to shed thousands of roles, the head of the UN's International Labour Organisation Gilbert Hungbo tells Aaron Heslehurst why the global jobs market is under pressure and why that could lead to more social unrest.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: Twenty-four hours a day, the latest national and international stories as they break.

programme.title: Our World
programme.desc: In 1972, Idi Amin publicly condemned Ugandan Asians as the enemy, enforcing a brutal policy that ordered them to leave the country within 90 days. It is estimated that up to 70,000 South Asians left Uganda in fear for their lives. On the 50th anniversary of the expulsion, BBC reporter Reha Kansara follows her mum and aunt as they return to Uganda together for the first time.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: Twenty-four hours a day, the latest national and international stories as they break.

programme.title: Click
programme.desc: Take a road trip around Las Vegas, underground in the tunnel system created by Elon Musk's Boring Company, above ground with the latest car sharing app, and in the sky.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: Twenty-four hours a day, the latest national and international stories as they break.

programme.title: The Media Show
programme.desc: Ros Atkins and guests explore what the rise of controversial social media influencer Andrew Tate tells us about modern masculinity and the media. Ros is joined by Matt Shea, the VICE journalist who investigated Tate, Helen Lewis, staff writer at The Atlantic and presenter of The New Gurus on BBC Sounds, and Professor Scott Galloway, host of the Prof G Pod and co-host of the Pivot podcast.

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: The BBC's Breakfast programme features the latest news, sport, business, weather and other items on a daily basis.

programme.title: Match of the Day
programme.desc: Gary Lineker introduces highlights of a busy day of Premier League football, featuring the blockbuster contest between Liverpool and Chelsea at Anfield. Liverpool have lost just one of the past eight Premier League meetings, although that defeat came on home turf in March 2021. Plus the best of the action from the other five fixtures.

programme.title: Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg
programme.desc: Laura Kuenssberg interviews first minister of Scotland and leader of the SNP Nicola Sturgeon MSP and shadow chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves MP.

programme.title: Politics London
programme.desc: The latest political news, interviews and debate.

programme.title: Sunday Morning Live
programme.desc: The UK government blocked Scotland's gender law reform which would have simplified the process for gaining a Gender Recognition Certificate. The team ask if it should be easier to change your legal sex. And, ahead of Holocaust Memorial Day, hear the harrowing story of a man who survived the Nazi death camps. Plus, meet the shopkeeper who's allowing customers to take goods without paying for them.

programme.title: Scotland's Sacred Islands With Ben Fogle
programme.desc: Ben returns to Taransay, the island where, over 20 years ago, he took part in the TV show `Castaway'. He visits Luskentyre Beach and joins local community members to learn how the island's remoteness sustains the sanctity of the Protestant Sabbath.

programme.title: Bargain Hunt
programme.desc: The show comes from an antiques fair at the home of horse racing, Newmarket racecourse. Charlie Ross is today's adjudicator and experts Colin Young and Jonathan Pratt help the reds and blues jockey for position as they hope to romp home with a profit at today's auction in Norfolk.

programme.title: Songs of Praise
programme.desc: The Songs of Praise Gospel Choir of the Year is back, hosted by Mark De-Lisser. In the first of two programmes, five of the best amateur choirs from across the UK take to the stage at The Monastery in Manchester. The choirs have to impress three celebrity judges - TV's favourite choir master Gareth Malone; actress, performer and queen of soul Mica Paris; and MOBO award-winning gospel artist and Christian rapper Guvna B. This week's five choirs each perform their take on a traditional hymn.

programme.title: Escape to the Country
programme.desc: Alistair Appleton is in the Welsh Borders helping a couple who have a healthy budget of £775,000 to find a countryside home to raise their young son and establish a glamping retreat business. Alistair also finds himself in a forest of fruit trees when he visits a perry and cider farm to find out about the region's drinks-making heritage.

programme.title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie
programme.desc: Two overly imaginative pranksters accidentally hypnotise their headmaster into thinking that he's a ridiculously enthusiastic, incredibly dim-witted superhero named Captain Underpants.

programme.title: Young MasterChef
programme.desc: The first five budding young cooks arrive for their initial taste of the Young MasterChef kitchen. They are a vegan entrepreneur from Knebworth, a DJ from Coventry, a paediatric nurse from Birmingham, a single mum from Dundee and a psychology student from Hackney.

programme.title: Young MasterChef
programme.desc: It's the second heat, and five new young cooks roll up their sleeves to face culinary superstars Poppy O'Toole and Kerth Gumbs. Facing the kitchen is a midwife from Swansea, a mechanical engineering student from Dunstable, a retirement village carer from West Bridgford, a food and hospitality student from Streatham and a lash artist from Tower Hamlets. The judges want to see the cooks' personality on a plate, one that tells them exactly who they are as a person and a cook.

programme.title: Serengeti
programme.desc: A great fire leaves homes destroyed and families separated. The animal characters must find new ways to survive in an unrecognisable and inhospitable landscape.

programme.title: Countryfile
programme.desc: It's 60 years since the Big Freeze, one of the coldest winters on record, when even the sea froze over, and rural communities were cut off by blizzards and towering snowdrifts. Anita Rani and Joe Crowley are in Flash, the UK's highest village, to see how the community coped then and how they brace for winter now. They also find out what sort of weather we can expect in future winters.

programme.desc: Robert and Catherine are determined that their family farm in Kent should move with the times. On top of growing wheat, in recent years they've branched out into making craft cider, inspired by family tradition and their Tamworth pigs.

programme.title: Escape to the Country
programme.desc: It's destination Argyll and Bute today. Sonali Shah tours this region of Scotland in search of a new home for a couple from a Warwickshire town who have a budget of £340,000. Sonali almost takes to the water on Loch Lomond, as she lends a hand to help a group of volunteers restoring the last paddle steamer to be built in Britain, a treasured relic of Scottish history.

programme.title: Panorama
programme.desc: A look at the increasingly close relationship between organised crime and dog dealing. Reporter Sam Poling infiltrates a network of dealers making millions by breeding dogs to extremes. She exposes how some drugs dealers have switched from dealing narcotics to dealing dogs, and shows how the growing popularity of breeds like American and French bulldogs has led some breeders to resort to cruel and dangerous tactics.

programme.title: The Bidding Room
programme.desc: Nigel Havers welcomes three more sellers to the Bidding Room, where they try to sell items to professional dealers who are on the lookout for interesting pieces, with help from expert Simon Bower. First through the doors is Kathy with a much-loved retro Battling Tops board game that has been the source of fun for many a family games night. Will the dealers be competing to win this one, or will it be game over for Kathy? Becky is selling a set of convertible shelves on behalf of her boss.

programme.title: Silent Witness
programme.desc: Levelling-up leaders and environmental activists clash in a small town trying to look to the future. With a sabotaged train and a dead mayor, the activists become suspects.

programme.title: Humza: Forgiving the Unforgivable

As a teenager, Humza's cousin suffered a brutal and unprovoked attack by a group of young men, an attack which left the family fragmented and scarred.

programme.title: The Graham Norton Show

programme.desc: Rapper Mist takes on Olympic boxer Nicola Adams in a game of hide and seek at a former nuclear bunker site. There's a sky full of drones, Mist gets schooled military style, and `Gunbird' takes flight.

programme.desc: Stephen is determined to find out who snitched on him about Class K's trip to a drag brunch. Meanwhile, Fraser mistakes an Ofsted inspector for a Task Rabbit.

programme.desc: Featuring The 21st Century Guide to Sex, and the mums return with some essential holiday tips.

programme.title: Young MasterChef
programme.desc: The pink neon lights of the kitchen are sparked, Poppy and Kerth have their forks at the ready, and the competition's best three cooks are ready to battle it out. It's the Young MasterChef final. The final challenge of this year's competition is a true celebration of everything these three remarkable finalists have learned so far.

programme.title: Zen School of Motoring
programme.desc: Ogmios discusses light-creepers, those scoundrels who creep forwards beyond the white line when the traffic lights are red. As part of his lesson on roundabouts, he takes a trip to Swindon to visit one of the world's greatest roundabouts.

programme.title: Gordon Ramsay's Future Food Stars
programme.desc: Gordon is celebrating the very best of British - exquisite produce and the pinnacle of fine dining. First, he invites his entrepreneurs to harvest oysters by hand on the glorious Essex coast. Using centuries-old techniques, they must collect as many restaurant-quality delicacies as they can. But it's tough out on the mud flats, and the contenders battle their surroundings to maintain quality control, exposed to the elements.

programme.title: Big Zuu's Big Eats
programme.desc: Big Zuu goes regal as he visits Royal Leamington Spa to prepare a feast for actor and comedian Guz Khan. In order to impress Guz, Zuu sets out to prepare both meat-based and plant-based dishes.

programme.title: Big Zuu's Big Eats
programme.desc: Big Zuu is back home in London as he prepares to cook for comedian Phil Wang whilst he tours with his show. Eager to impress, Zuu's mum is enlisted to help make the perfect jollof rice.

programme.title: Meet the Khans: Big in Bolton
programme.desc: The Khans are back at the wedding hall, again. The couple are shown around the building as they discuss their big plans for the space. Amir Khan and his team volunteer to pack and deliver food parcels across the town to those in need, Faryal and Khadija let off some steam in a rage room, and Amir and Faryal go on a much-needed date night.

programme.title: Ryan Tricks On The Street
programme.desc: Ryan's mother bought him his first magic set for Christmas and seeing the look of amazement on his mum's face after he performed his first trick inspired him to become the magician that he is today. Ryan wants to pass on the gift the magic and who better than a group of young mums on a well-earned trip out, sans kids, for a break and a bit of a laugh.

programme.title: Wagspiracy: Vardy v Rooney
programme.desc: In 2019, `Wagatha Christie' gripped Britain as Coleen Rooney accused Rebekah Vardy of leaking stories about her to the tabloid press. Despite huge media attention on this social media scandal, and a trial that ended up in the high-court in the summer of 2022, with Rooney emerging victorious, the inside story of how and why this extraordinary moment in British culture came to pass, has never fully been told, until now.

programme.title: Ben Is Back
programme.desc: A young man with a drug addiction unexpectedly returns to his family's home for Christmas. Over the next 24 hours, new truths are revealed as his mother does everything possible to keep him clean.
